citations.narrative:
In building #5, three enclosures housing a total of 3 adults and 1 puppy had excessively damaged carpet squares. This
was corrected at the time of inspection. The damaged carpet squares could cause injury to an animal should it become
entangled in the shredded fibers and could have a negative impact on the health of an animal should the animals swallow
damaged carpet materials.
Housing facilities for dogs must be maintained in good repair and protect the dogs from injury. The licensee must remove
the damaged carpet squares or alter them in a manner that eliminates the risk of injury to the dogs. The licensee must
maintain all enclosures in good repair at all times.
To be corrected by: 6-December-2023
In building #3, an enclosure housing one adult dog has a piece of broken metal trim that was rusted and sharp and
sticking out into the enclosure. This was corrected at the time of inspection.
In building #5, several enclosures have small screws protruding into the top of the primary enclosure's. The screws were
approximately 1/4-1/2" inches long into the enclosure and were sharp on the ends. A dog may be able to come into
contact if they were to jump in the enclosure or stand on their hind legs. Contact with sharp points could cause injury to
the dog.
Housing facilities for dogs must be maintained in good repair and protect the animals from injury. The licensee must either
remove the sharp points or alter them in a manner that eliminates the risk of injury to the dogs. The licensee must ensure
that all enclosures are safe for the dogs at all times.
To be corrected by: 26-December-2023
Two sheltered primary enclosures each containing one adult dog had plastic material on the wall of their outdoor section
that has been excessively chewed on. These surfaces are no longer in good repair and chewing on plastic could have a
negative impact on the health of an animal should the animals swallow pieces of plastic
Housing facilities for dogs must be maintained in good repair and protect the animals from injury. The licensee must either
remove the plastic board or alter them in a manner that eliminates the risk of injury to the dog and ensure the enclosures
remain in good repair at all times.
To be corrected by: 26-December-2023

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At least three sheltered primary enclosures each housing one adult dog have an excessive buildup of feces in the outdoor
section. The facility representative states it has been a couple of days since those enclosures were cleaned. One adult
Bichon had dried fecal material present in the hair on the rear feet, the representative stated the enclosures will be
cleaned and sanitized today and this dog will receive a bath today. A buildup of feces could cause the dog to become
soiled, could attract pests, and could also increase the risk of disease.
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures daily. The licensee must remove the feces from the
affected enclosure and ensure that all waste is removed from each enclosure daily.
To be corrected by: End of business 5-December-2023

Male Bichon (MC#977200009776858) is currently being treated for "hot spots" on the rear legs with Vetricyn wound spray
twice a day for the last 3-4 days. The licensee is not keeping medical records of when the problem was identified and
treatments being given.
Without proper documentation, it is difficult to determine the efficacy of a treatment plan and ensure the animals are
receiving adequate veterinary care. A proper medical record includes the date the problem was found, a description of the
problem, the name and frequency and amount of medications used, examination findings, test results, plans for treatment
and care, and treatment procedures performed must be recorded and a copy kept for review for inspection by APHIS
officials. Correct by ensuring all records of any treatments for problems identified in the dogs are recorded and maintained
at all times.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
In building #5, three enclosures housing a total of 3 adults and 1 puppy had excessively damaged carpet squares. This 
was corrected at the time of inspection. The damaged carpet squares could cause injury to an animal should it become 
entangled in the shredded fibers and could have a negative impact on the health of an animal should the animals swallow 
damaged carpet materials. 
Housing facilities for dogs must be maintained in good repair and protect the dogs from injury. The licensee must remove 
the damaged carpet squares or alter them in a manner that eliminates the risk of injury to the dogs. The licensee must 
maintain all enclosures in good repair at all times. 
To be corrected by: 6-December-2023 
 
In building #3, an enclosure housing one adult dog has a piece of broken metal trim that was rusted and sharp and 
sticking out into the enclosure. This was corrected at the time of inspection. 
In building #5, several enclosures have small screws protruding into the top of the primary enclosure's. The screws were 
approximately 1/4-1/2" inches long into the enclosure and were sharp on the ends. A dog may be able to come into 
contact if they were to jump in the enclosure or stand on their hind legs. Contact with sharp points could cause injury to 
the dog. 
Housing facilities for dogs must be maintained in good repair and protect the animals from injury. The licensee must either 
remove the sharp points or alter them in a manner that eliminates the risk of injury to the dogs. The licensee must ensure 
that all enclosures are safe for the dogs at all times. 
To be corrected by: 26-December-2023 
 
Two sheltered primary enclosures each containing one adult dog had plastic material on the wall of their outdoor section 
that has been excessively chewed on. These surfaces are no longer in good repair and chewing on plastic could have a 
negative impact on the health of an animal should the animals swallow pieces of plastic 
Housing facilities for dogs must be maintained in good repair and protect the animals from injury. The licensee must either 
remove the plastic board or alter them in a manner that eliminates the risk of injury to the dog and ensure the enclosures 
remain in good repair at all times. 
To be corrected by: 26-December-2023 
3.11(a)

Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
At least three sheltered primary enclosures each housing one adult dog have an excessive buildup of feces in the outdoor 
section. The facility representative states it has been a couple of days since those enclosures were cleaned. One adult 
Bichon had dried fecal material present in the hair on the rear feet, the representative stated the enclosures will be 
cleaned and sanitized today and this dog will receive a bath today. A buildup of feces could cause the dog to become 
soiled, could attract pests, and could also increase the risk of disease. 
Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures daily. The licensee must remove the feces from the 
affected enclosure and ensure that all waste is removed from each enclosure daily. 
To be corrected by: End of business 5-December-2023 
3.13(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Male Bichon (MC#977200009776858) is currently being treated for "hot spots" on the rear legs with Vetricyn wound spray 
twice a day for the last 3-4 days. The licensee is not keeping medical records of when the problem was identified and 
treatments being given. 
Without proper documentation, it is difficult to determine the efficacy of a treatment plan and ensure the animals are 
receiving adequate veterinary care. A proper medical record includes the date the problem was found, a description of the 
problem, the name and frequency and amount of medications used, examination findings, test results, plans for treatment 
and care, and treatment procedures performed must be recorded and a copy kept for review for inspection by APHIS 
officials. Correct by ensuring all records of any treatments for problems identified in the dogs are recorded and maintained 
at all times. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
